patch_unified:
diff --git a/docs/reference/setup.asciidoc b/docs/reference/setup.asciidoc
index 1d2fb18..fa2a6ce 100644
--- a/docs/reference/setup.asciidoc
+++ b/docs/reference/setup.asciidoc
@@ -27,6 +27,46 @@ To run it in the background, add the `-d` switch to it:
 $ bin/elasticsearch -d
 --------------------------------------------------
 
+=== Package Installation
+
+If you have installed Elasticsearch using a package manager (deb or rpm),
+the service will not start automatically after installation. You need to start it manually.
+
+For systems using systemd:
+
+[source,sh]
+--------------------------------------------------
+$ sudo systemctl start elasticsearch.service
+--------------------------------------------------
+
+For systems using SysV init:
+
+[source,sh]
+--------------------------------------------------
+$ sudo service elasticsearch start
+--------------------------------------------------
+
+Or directly:
+
+[source,sh]
+--------------------------------------------------
+$ sudo /etc/init.d/elasticsearch start
+--------------------------------------------------
+
+To enable Elasticsearch to start automatically on system boot:
+
+[source,sh]
+--------------------------------------------------
+$ sudo systemctl enable elasticsearch.service
+--------------------------------------------------
+
+For SysV init systems:
+
+[source,sh]
+--------------------------------------------------
+$ sudo chkconfig elasticsearch on
+--------------------------------------------------
+
 ElasticSearch is built using Java, and requires at least
 http://java.sun.com/javase/downloads/index.jsp[Java 6] in order to run.
 The version of Java that will be used can be set by setting the
diff --git a/docs/reference/setup/as-a-service.asciidoc b/docs/reference/setup/as-a-service.asciidoc
index d8a935b..e4654d2 100644
--- a/docs/reference/setup/as-a-service.asciidoc
+++ b/docs/reference/setup/as-a-service.asciidoc
@@ -7,6 +7,16 @@ In order to run elasticsearch as a service on your operating system, the provide
 
 Currently our build automatically creates a debian package and an RPM package, which is available on the download page. The package itself does not have any dependencies, but you have to make sure that you installed a JDK.
 
+IMPORTANT: After installing the package, Elasticsearch will not start automatically. You need to start it manually using one of the following commands:
+
+* For systemd systems: `sudo systemctl start elasticsearch.service`
+* For SysV init systems: `sudo service elasticsearch start`
+
+You can also enable Elasticsearch to start automatically on system boot:
+
+* For systemd systems: `sudo systemctl enable elasticsearch.service`
+* For SysV init systems: `sudo chkconfig elasticsearch on`
+
 Each package features a configuration file, which allows you to set the following parameters
 
 [horizontal]
diff --git a/src/deb/control/postinst b/src/deb/control/postinst
index 1e14e8a..0da6bae 100755
--- a/src/deb/control/postinst
+++ b/src/deb/control/postinst
@@ -40,9 +40,16 @@ case "$1" in
 	# if $2 is set, this is an upgrade
 	if ( [ -n $2 ] && [ "$RESTART_ON_UPGRADE" = "true" ] ) ; then
 		startElasticsearch
-	# this is a fresh installation, start anyway
+	# this is a fresh installation, do not start automatically
 	elif [ -z $2 ] ; then
-		startElasticsearch
+		# Elasticsearch will not start automatically after installation
+		# To start Elasticsearch manually, use:
+		#   service elasticsearch start
+		#   or
+		#   /etc/init.d/elasticsearch start
+		# Note: If you want the old behavior (automatic startup), 
+		# uncomment the line below:
+		# startElasticsearch
 	fi
 	;;
 esac
diff --git a/src/rpm/scripts/postinstall b/src/rpm/scripts/postinstall
index aefbea3..092810a 100644
--- a/src/rpm/scripts/postinstall
+++ b/src/rpm/scripts/postinstall
@@ -35,7 +35,16 @@ if [ $1 -eq 1 ] ; then
         /sbin/chkconfig --add elasticsearch
     fi
 
-	startElasticsearch
+	# Elasticsearch will not start automatically after installation
+	# To start Elasticsearch manually, use:
+	#   systemctl start elasticsearch.service (for systemd)
+	#   or
+	#   service elasticsearch start (for SysV init)
+	#   or
+	#   /etc/init.d/elasticsearch start
+	# Note: If you want the old behavior (automatic startup), 
+	# uncomment the line below:
+	# startElasticsearch
 elif [ $1 -ge 2 -a "$RESTART_ON_UPGRADE" == "true" ] ; then
 	stopElasticsearch
 	startElasticsearch
